justification: The study shows that finger speed during decision making provides an implicit online measure of instantaneous confidence. Fluctuations in finger speed correlate with post-decision confidence ratings, suggesting it tracks online confidence in real-time.

Participants rated their subjective confidence after each decision on a continuous vertical scale. This explicit measure of confidence was correlated with other measures like accuracy and movement speed, validating its use as an indicator of confidence.
The accuracy of decisions was measured by the number of correct responses in each condition, providing a straightforward measure of how well participants performed in the task.
The trajectory of the participants' finger movement was tracked continuously, revealing how evidence accumulation and confidence evolve over time in the decision-making process.
